Letter to the editor: 
It has become clear to me that this whole voter fraud insistence by President Trump is the new “wag the dog” to keep the nation’s attention from the real bite. Stephen Miller, policy aide to the president, commanded viewers to focus on voter fraud and his condescending tone almost dared anyone to not concentrate on this issue above other suspicious issues like Russian involvement with now ex-National Security Adviser Michael Flynn and others in power in the current administration. As a country, we must be vigilant and act swiftly. Innocent until proven guilty seems naive in the face of harder and harder to prove innocence. Let’s not become distracted. We must stay the course of investigating what ties there are between our new administration and Russia. 
It is fun to laugh at Saturday Night Live’s satirical sketches with comedians playing the parts of Russian President Vladimir Putin and Trump, but this is no laughing matter. Wage war against collusion and corruption at the top! 
Lynn Barry; Hume, N.Y. Policing the USA 
Letter to the editor: 
Ivanka, Eric and Donald Trump Jr. must stand up and persuade their father to step down as president. 
Trump’s disrespect for the presidency is corrupting our political culture. His mendacity in spreading toxic lies about anyone who opposes his pursuit of power is bottomless. His ignorance of the basic functions and responsibilities of the presidency is inexplicable. His likely compromising of American security and sovereignty with political, financial and personal connections with Russia is unprecedented in American history. 
Trump is a broken person who, at age 70, cannot be made whole. He cannot be shamed into resigning. He will not be impeached by congressional Republicans, who don’t possess a shred of decency and patriotism to do so. Only the kids can save their father and their brand from further shame and inevitable destruction. It doesn’t matter if they don’t do it to save the dignity and importance of the presidency. It doesn’t matter if they don’t do it to prevent the next war. It’s OK if their motives are strictly personal and familial. They just need to do it. 
Walt Zlotow; Glen Ellyn, Ill. 
We asked our followers to share their thoughts on interactions between Russian officials and President Trump’s campaign. Tweets are edited for clarity and grammar: 
It’s a disgrace for this country. It looks like Trump is in it, up to his eyeballs. Let’s call it #Trustgate, it needs a name. 
— @BartRehbein_59 
The truth lies somewhere in the middle. Frankly, both sides are party to this activity, always. 
— @PirateVoice1952 
Treason is treason. Ongoing discussion with Russia during campaign process, at the very least, demands scrutiny. 
— @MelissaMermaid 
Did anyone care about the Clinton Foundation’s interactions with the Russians? I think that would be a “no.” 
— @CarolynD72355 
When you keep information from your vice president, when you try to deflect or say, well so-and-so did such-and-such, there is definitely something underhanded. 
— @angelmhunter
